EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small tornado skipped across a residential housing development causing minor damage to houses.  A number of trees were toppled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wide spread heavy precipatation from Pacific storm. SFO 1.4 santa Cruz 2.0" Boulder Creek 2.3" Kentfield 2.0". Large pine tree fell through home in Oakland due to the wet soil and wind in the storm. power was out to as many as 3500 people in the area. Traffic accidents were nearly double normal with 200 during the afternoon commute."

EVENT_NARRATIVE: rain slick road and poor visibility caused auto accident
Smal hail fell in and around the Oakland Zoo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat advisory conditions were experienced in the East Bay Valleys for several days in late August. Temperatures soared to as high as 112 degrees in some locations, with overnight lows holding in the mid and upper 70s. Several reports of heat related illness were reported.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intense heat settled over the East Bay Hills during this 5 day stretch in August. Temperatures at Mt.Diablo soared to over 100 degrees for 5 consecutive days with lows hovering near 80.

A large dome of High Pressure brought hot conditions to the SF Bay Shoreline - with a moist southeast flow keeping temperatures unusually warm overnight. High temperatures reached as high as 103 degrees with low temperatures at night only falling into the lower 70s.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing temperatures over the period caused approximately $400,000 in crop damage - mainly to flowers. Low temperatures fell into the 20s and lower 30s many nights during this period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Record cold wave settled upon the San Francisco and Monterey Bay Areas from January 6th through January 19th. Numerous record lows were experienced and agricultural damage totalled over $1 Billion State-Wide. Counties in the San Francisco and Monterey Bay areas reported damage in excess of $20 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 11-month-old boy died in the back seat of the family car in Concord on July 25,2007 after his father apparently forgot to drop him off at day care and instead left him locked inside the vehicle while he spent the day at work. High temperatures in the area were generally around 85. |
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An 11-month-old boy died in the back seat of the family car in Concord on July 25,2007 after his father apparently forgot to drop him off at day care and instead left him locked inside the vehicle while he spent the day at work.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused many vehicle collisions in the San Francisco East Bay area on Saturday. One crash in particular resulted in a vehicle carrying six passengers flipping into the canal that splits Hegenberger Expressway near Hamilton Street in Oakland. The nineteen year old male driver died in the crash (indirect fatality).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm winter storm brought heavy rain to Northern and Central California inducing debris flows over recent fire scarred areas, causing power outages, downing trees and causing numerous traffic collisions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing temperatures combined with residual moisture from the previous days' rain to cause several minor traffic accidents. Icy conditions led to at least three collisions on Highway 4, Highway 24, and on San Pablo Dam Road. Also, black ice is suspected as the culprit in two other accidents, one in Martinez and the other in Pleasanton.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold core low pressure system produced winter storm conditions causing low elevation snow, minor flooding and isolated strong wind through the period December 15 through 17, 2009. Snow amounts ranged from a few inches in the hills around the San Francisco Bay Area to as high as nine inches at Mount Hamilton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An overloaded electric transformer failed in Oakland causing more than 5,000 customers to lose power for about three hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft centered over Reno, NV along with weak offshore flow at the surface caused temperatures to rise to near 100 degrees in the inland valleys of north-central California. Heat exhausted individuals, blown electric transformers and power outages accompanied the heat.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several people sought medical attention due to heat-induced fainting spells in Anitoch and Walnut Creek. Also, an electric transformer failed sparking a fire in Walnut Creek near the intersection of Wiget Lane and Ygnacio Valley Road causing 108 customers to lose power. The fire damaged nearby vegetation and an olive tree.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft centered over Reno, NV along with weak offshore flow at the surface caused temperatures to rise to near 100 degrees in the inland valleys of north-central California. Heat exhausted individuals, blown electric transformers and power outages accompanied the heat.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures rose into the upper 80s to mid 90s across the mountains of the East San Francisco Bay Area. One hiker was escorted off of Mount Diablo by fire fighter due to heat exhaustion.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft centered over Reno, NV along with weak offshore flow at the surface caused temperatures to rise to near 100 degrees in the inland valleys of north-central California. Heat exhausted individuals, blown electric transformers and power outages accompanied the heat.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A father and son were hiking during the hottest time of the day when the father collapse due to heat exhaustion and dehydration. The father died on the trail and the boy was taken to a hospital where he recovered.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the San Francisco Bay Area along with weak surface flow caused afternoon temperatures to rise well above average for locations inland from the coast.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damage was done to an underground utility trench along Crest Road in Piedmont from torrential rains. Rain water found its way through cracks in the sidewalk and percolated up through the street. As a result, two and a half feet of sand covering a conduit was disturbed or washed away leaving damaged sidewalks.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system made its way through Northern and Central California accompanied by deep tropical moisture and very strong winds.  Heavy rain combined with the wind to cause numerous trees, tree limbs and pole/telephone powers to fall.  Pacific Gas and Electric reported over 277,000 customers had lost power in the San Francisco and Monterey Bay Areas with a cost of over thirteen million dollars in damages.  The record breaking heavy rain also led to flooding and debris flows.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cold winter storm caused snow to fall in San Francisco's East Bay valleys as low as 350 feet above sea level. Locations such as Clayton, Alamo, Orinda, Moraga, Danville, Lamorinda, and the Livermore Valley all reported snow. It may have only been two inches at most, but it was enough to play in and cause some traffic problems.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved southward out of western Canada and into California causing snow to fall as low as 350 feet above sea level in San Francisco's East Bay Area.  In the East Bay Mountains over six inches of snow was reported. Also, small hail was observed throughout the Bay Area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to minor flooding of westbound Interstate 580 west of State Highway 24. An inch of water spread into about five feet of the right-hand lane. Also, The High Street on-ramp to northbound Interstate 880 was flooded due to poor drainage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first significant storm of the season brought strong winds and heavy rain to the San Francisco Bay Area. A low pressure trough from the Gulf of Alaska dropped far enough south to drench the region causing trees to fall and minor flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two cars collided on westbound I-580 near Benedict Drive in San Leandro.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of storm systems from the Gulf of Alaska brought gusty winds and periods of heavy rain across the San Francisco and Monterey Bay areas from March 13 through March 16, 2012.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 72 Hour Rainfall total of 3.08 inches was the peak for Alameda County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm finally impacted California following up on nearly a month and a half of no rain and the driest January on record. The storm brought heavy rain, gusty winds, and damage to trees and power lines along with some minor flooding of urban areas. Rainfall amounts were heaviest in the mountains with 5-10 inches or more occurring. Generally 1-3.5 inches fell in low elevation areas and urban spots, with less than an inch in Southern Monterey County. Winds gusted 50-70 MPH with the highest gusts in the mountains of the region. Several small mudslides were reported with the largest occurring in the Santa Cruz Mountains north of Boulder Creek on Highway 9.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damage dollar amounts is a low estimate. Impacts are not fully known, but any individual car crash would likely exceed this amount.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second in a series of three storms between January 18-23. Storm two occurred January 19-20. Heavy rain, strong winds, and small hail were observed with this frontal system as well as lightning strikes in San Francisco.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea sized hail reported by spotter. Several other reports of pea sized hail also.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Third in a series of three storm systems occurred from January 22 to January 23. Heavy rain, lightning, wind, hail, snow (above 2500 ft), and record breaking surf were observed with this system.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree crashed into a KFC in Newark causing damage to the property. Wind damage likely from previous night. Fremont RAWS reported gust of 44 mph previous night.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level trough with associated cold front moved through on April 6th causing roadway flooding, gusty winds over both land and sea, as well as strong swells which sunk a Bart Barge over the SF Bay. Post frontal conditions on the 8th brought scattered showers, frigid temperatures, and isolated thunderstorms with small hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 5,000 residents in Livermore and over 2,000 in Concord lost power due to the heat|http://abc7news.com/weather/thousands-left-without-power-on-scorching-hot-day/2116951/ http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2017/06/20/bay-area-heat-wave-flex-alert-conserve-electricity/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Bay Area had its first summer heat wave starting June 17th and lasting until the 23rd. Strong high pressure and offshore flow brought record breaking heat to the area not seen since 2008 and 2006. The heat wave stretched across much of the rest of the state as well as the Desert Southwest. Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings were issued across the Central Coast. There were at least two confirmed human fatalities in Santa Clara county from the heat as well as widespread power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several hundred residents were without power across the San Francisco Bay Area on Tuesday night due to the heat http://www.ktvu.com/weather/weather-news-headlines/262766743-story.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Bay Area had its first summer heat wave starting June 17th and lasting until the 23rd. Strong high pressure and offshore flow brought record breaking heat to the area not seen since 2008 and 2006. The heat wave stretched across much of the rest of the state as well as the Desert Southwest. Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings were issued across the Central Coast. There were at least two confirmed human fatalities in Santa Clara county from the heat as well as widespread power outages.
Isolated thunderstorms developed behind a cold front that passed through the area on the 25th. These thunderstorms caused minor roadway flooding and small hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of pea-sized hail in Oakland via social media.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system with a strong cold front moved through the Bay Area at the turn of the month with precipitation beginning late the evening of the 28th. This system brought widespread rainfall causing localized roadway flooding, strong winds, lightning, and small hail. Gusts in the mountains reached 60 mph and hail was seen up to 1/2 an inch. The bulk of the precipitation and subsequent impacts were seen in early March.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea-sized hail reported in north Berkeley via social media.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea-sized hail in north Pleasanton south of I-580.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved through the area on the afternoon of the 14th. This disturbance created scattered thunderstorms that resulted in lightning and accumulating hail in the North and East Bay areas.
A short-wave disturbance along with a trough moved through the Bay Area. The resulting instability generated scattered thunderstorms that produced small hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported pea-sized hail, thunder, and lightning near I-580/I-680 in north Pleasanton.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short-wave disturbance along with a trough moved through the Bay Area. The resulting instability generated scattered thunderstorms that produced small hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small accumulating hail observed in Oakland.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season deep upper level trough moved southward along the California coast bringing rain and gusty winds to the region. Scattered convection was produced in the wake of an associated cold front bringing widespread small hail, thunder, and lightning to the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small hail observed in east Oakland.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain causes a section of the roof at a West Oakland warehouse to cave in overnight. Timing of event is uncertain https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2018/11/29/potent-storm-brings-heavy-rain-pounding-surf-high-winds-and-flooding/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid/upper level low moved through the region at the end of November. A cool unstable air mass allowed for the development of scattered thunderstorms across the region that produced lightning and small hail. An associated surface low approached the coast during this time causing high surf and gusty winds. Some locations saw wave heights above 25 feet. This system caused roadway flooding, minor debris flows, and downed trees along with damage from gusty winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Concord airport recorded visibility of a quarter mile or less.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Interior valley fog that drifted into the East Bay brought visibility down to less than 1/4 mile. This prompted a Dense Fog Advisory to be issued for the East Bay valleys.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quarter mile visibility or less was reported at Livermore Airport.

A Dense Fog Advisory was issued for the North and East Bay Valleys as well as the San Francisco Peninsula and surrounding bay coastline. Fog caused numerous diverts at KSFO.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported small hail east of Pleasanton.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the Bay Area on January 20th bringing gusty west to northwest winds to the coast and scattered thunderstorms. Several reports were received of small hail.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow reported on Mt Hamilton, snow depth 8 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid/upper low with a very cold airmass moved through in early February bringing snow to lower elevation peaks across the region prompting a rare Winter Weather Advisory. Junipero Serra Peak received around a foot of snow. Rainfall just ahead of this system also brought roadway flooding and minor debris flows.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimate of 3 inches of snow on Mt Diablo summit trail 24 hours after snow fell.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated 1.5 inches of snow on the ground 5 miles N of Milpitas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the region into February 10th lowering snow levels below 1500 ft, per the Bodega Bay Profiler. The areas peaks saw another dusting to several inches of snow as a result with Mount Hamilton recording almost 6 inches. Additionally, showers ahead of the front the previous evening caused some minor roadway flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cal OSHA reported a heat related illness in Pleasanton on the 24th. Afternoon high temperature at the Livermore airport was 92 degrees. Time estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cal OSHA reported a heat related illness in Pleasanton on the 24th. Afternoon high temperature at the Livermore airport was 92 degrees. Many locations across the interior were in the low 90s with some coastal locations even reaching the 80s. Three daily record high temperatures were either tied or broken.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat wave across the region triggered power outages knocking out service to 26,400 people across 9 counties on Monday followed by an additional 30,400 on Tuesday https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2019/06/11/pge-transformers-in-bay-area-cant-always-cope-with-heat-waves/?utm_campaign=socialflow&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_content=tw-EastBayTimes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of high pressure and strong offshore flow resulted in an early season heat wave across the Bay Area from June 9th to the 11th. Multiple daily records were broken across the region and multiple power outages were reported due to the heat. Approximately 26,000 people across the region lost power on Monday followed by an additional 30,000 on Tuesday. Three fatalities were reported during the heat event. One man died as a direct result of heat related illness while two others drowned while attempting to cool down during the heat wave. Hot temperatures and dry grass resulted in a vegetation fire that spread to a residence.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat across the region caused 26,400 people to lose power on Monday followed by an additional 30,400 on Tuesdsay https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/The-Heat-is-On-Bay-Area-Expected-to-Continue-Seeing-Scorching-Temperatures-511107952.html.

The hot temperatures made fire fighting efforts difficult resulting in one firefighter suffering from heat exhaustion http://www.ktvu.com/news/ktvu-local-news/firefighter-suffers-heat-exhaustion-battling-house-fire-in-east-foothills-of-san-jose.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire in Oakley prompted evacuations and a preemptive power shutoff for 5600 customers. Fire officials said 58 acres were burned and 2 structures were destroyed https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Firefighters-Battle-Vegetation-Fire-in-Oakley-525973021.html.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brush fire in Oakley prompted evacuations and a preemptive power shutoff for 5600 customers. Fire officials said 58 acres were burned and 2 structures were destroyed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The start of the school year for some in Pittsburg was delayed due to the heat https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2019/08/15/heat-wave-liberty-high-brentwood-early-practice-pittsburg-highlands-elementary-postponed/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure building over the Desert Southwest brought a heat wave to the Bay Area in mid August. Multiple daily high temperature records were broken across the region. Heat prompted the delay of the school year for some students. Additionally, the heat caused a large power outage in the East Bay leaving thousands of residents without power.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat caused multiple power outages across portions of the East Bay leaving thousands of residents without power https://www.kron4.com/news/bay-area/extreme-heat-causes-major-power-outage-in-danville/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure building over the Desert Southwest brought a heat wave to the Bay Area in mid August. Multiple daily high temperature records were broken across the region. Heat prompted the delay of the school year for some students. Additionally, the heat caused a large power outage in the East Bay leaving thousands of residents without power.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small wildfire broke out in the hills near Moraga overnight prompting evacuations for nearby homes. Ultimately no structures were destroyed https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2019/10/10/fire-crews-battle-merrill-fire-in-moraga/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed over the North and East Bay Hills. This along with a very dry airmass over the region, created critical fire weather conditions for the greater Bay Area. Scattered wildfires broke out across Northern California on Thursday the 10th at least one of which prompted the issuance of evacuations.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Under critical fire weather conditions a wildfire broke out southeast of Livermore in Alameda County. The Mines Fire burned 35 acres https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2019/10/24/mines-fire/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of offshore wind events plagued much of California towards the end of October. Cut off lows (also known as insider sliders) moved into the Great Basin as an upper ridge sat over the eastern Pacific. Strong surface high pressure also building over the Great Basin and a trough along the California coast provided the set up for strong and dry offshore winds over the greater Bay Area. Two more such events would go on to occur before the end of the month providing what would be historic critical fire weather conditions for the region. The first event brought strong N to NE winds to the region, particularly the North Bay, where gusts of 50 to 70 mph were observed. Healdsburg Hills North Station had a peak gust of 76 mph the night of the 23rd. These conditions fed the rapid growth of the Kincade Fire that broke out late in the evening on the 23rd, and at the end of the month was still burning. Additionally, near record breaking high temperatures were observed in parts of the area on the 24th and 25th. Prior to the event PG&E shut off power to  roughly 1 million people across the state of California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several wildfires broke out into Sunday morning around the region. One of them (Cypress Complex) was sparked early Sunday morning prompting the issuance of limited evacuations of nearby neighborhoods. Ultimately no structures were destroyed https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2019/10/27/cypress-complex/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of offshore wind events plagued much of California towards the end of October. Cut off lows (also known as insider sliders) moved into the Great Basin as an upper ridge sat over the eastern Pacific. Strong surface high pressure also building over the Great Basin and a trough along the California coast provided the set up for one of the strongest dry offshore winds over the greater Bay Area since the 2017 North Bay Fires. Winds remained elevated for at least 24 hours with gusts in the hills 60 to 80 mph. A peak gust of 102 mph was recorded near the Kincade Fire. These winds promoted rapid growth of the Kincade Fire and along with very dry conditions allowed for multiple new wildfires to spark in the greater Bay Area. A large amount of the community in Sonoma County was evacuated downwind of the Kincade Fire in response. Prior to the event PG&E shut off power to over 2 million people across the state of California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fires sparked around the same time Sunday morning opposite of the Carquinez Strait one in Vallejo and the other in Crockett. The fire on the Contra Costa County side was named the Sky Fire. Both fires caused evacuations in Contra Costa and Solano Counties while shutting down I-80 and the Carquinez Bridge. The Sky Fire in the end burned around 150 acres and did not damage any structures https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2019/10/27/sky-fire/ |https://www.sfchronicle.com/california-wildfires/article/Vallejo-Fire-Interstate-80-Carquinez-Bridge-14566204.php.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of offshore wind events plagued much of California towards the end of October. Cut off lows (also known as insider sliders) moved into the Great Basin as an upper ridge sat over the eastern Pacific. Strong surface high pressure also building over the Great Basin and a trough along the California coast provided the set up for one of the strongest dry offshore winds over the greater Bay Area since the 2017 North Bay Fires. Winds remained elevated for at least 24 hours with gusts in the hills 60 to 80 mph. A peak gust of 102 mph was recorded near the Kincade Fire. These winds promoted rapid growth of the Kincade Fire and along with very dry conditions allowed for multiple new wildfires to spark in the greater Bay Area. A large amount of the community in Sonoma County was evacuated downwind of the Kincade Fire in response. Prior to the event PG&E shut off power to over 2 million people across the state of California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fires broke out on either side of Hwy 24 in Lafayette and Martinez. The Lafayette Fire was named the Pleasant Fire prompted evacuations. The fire grew to 7 acres and burned three structures including a Lafayette Tennis Club Building and one home https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2019-10-27/east-bay-fire-prompts-evacuations-in-lafayette.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of offshore wind events plagued much of California towards the end of October. Cut off lows (also known as insider sliders) moved into the Great Basin as an upper ridge sat over the eastern Pacific. Strong surface high pressure also building over the Great Basin and a trough along the California coast provided the set up for one of the strongest dry offshore winds over the greater Bay Area since the 2017 North Bay Fires. Winds remained elevated for at least 24 hours with gusts in the hills 60 to 80 mph. A peak gust of 102 mph was recorded near the Kincade Fire. These winds promoted rapid growth of the Kincade Fire and along with very dry conditions allowed for multiple new wildfires to spark in the greater Bay Area. A large amount of the community in Sonoma County was evacuated downwind of the Kincade Fire in response. Prior to the event PG&E shut off power to over 2 million people across the state of California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fire broke out in a residential neighborhood in Milpitas. One home was destroyed and 3 others were damaged https://www.mercurynews.com/2019/10/27/four-structures-on-fire-in-milpitas-neighborhood/.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wildfire broke out in Martinez Sunday afternoon prompting evacuations in nearby residential areas. Named the Forest Fire, it burned about 50 acres but no structures were destroyed and no injuries reported https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2019/10/27/fire-rapid-spread-forces-evacuations-martinez-alhambra-ave/.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Livermore Airport ASOS recorded reduced visibilities down to 1/4 mile or less due to dense fog.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the aftermath of a weak weather system, residual low level moisture caused dense fog to develop around San Francisco and the surrounding areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Concord Airport ASOS recorded reduced visibilities of 1/4 mile due to dense fog.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Oakland Airport ASOS recorded reduced visibilities due to dense fog. The majority of the time period saw visibility down to 1/4 mile.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the aftermath of a weak weather system, residual low level moisture caused dense fog to develop around San Francisco and the surrounding areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reporting pea-sized hail in Alameda. Reported via twitter.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying and ultimately record setting low pressure system moved into northern California and the Pacific Northwest in late November. A strong cold front associated with this system swept through the Bay Area bringing heavy rain, roadway flooding, strong winds, low elevation snow, small hail, and large waves to the region. This low set a record for the lowest sea-level pressure ever recorded in the state of California near Crescent City of 973.4 mb. Numerous webcams picked up snow on our area peaks down to 2000 feet in elevation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Oakland Airport ASOS recorded visibility down to a quarter mile or less during the majority of this time period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Residual low-level moisture from recent rainfall in combination with longer December nights and a stable airmass allowed for the formation of dense fog across the North and East Bay Valleys  as well as along the San Francisco Bay shoreline. Multiple airports recorded visibility down to a quarter of a mile or less.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Livermore Airport ASOS recorded visibility down to a quarter mile or less.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reports heavy snow on SR-130 near the Lick Observatory on Mount Hamilton. Several inches of snow, could end up being 1 foot.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent cold front swept through the region on January 16th bringing widespread rain, gusty winds, low elevation snow, and thunderstorms. This system brought widespread roadway flooding, downed trees, small hail, and snow as low as 2400 ft in elevation. Numerous flights were delayed or canceled at SFO due to the weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rice sized hail reported by spotter.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent cold front swept through the region on January 16th bringing widespread rain, gusty winds, low elevation snow, and thunderstorms. This system brought widespread roadway flooding, downed trees, small hail, and snow as low as 2400 ft in elevation. Numerous flights were delayed or canceled at SFO due to the weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm cell moved over the East Bay in the afternoon producing small hail over Livermore and Pleasanton.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper low brought several days of showers across the Greater Bay Area. The system was very slow to exit the region, with lingering instability over the southern portion of the area generating multiple convective cells that produced small hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Willow Fire broke out in Contra Costa County late Saturday afternoon. Like the other wildfires that day, this one was aided in spread by gusty winds https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/06/06/map-seven-fires-amid-high-winds-in-the-bay-area/. Exact end time uncertain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low along with a second shortwave trough moved through the region the first weekend of June. A strong onshore pressure gradient brought gusty winds to much of the area. Observations showed gusts of 40 to 60 mph throughout the Bay Area and Central Coast. These winds fueled multiple grass and vegetation fires throughout the area, some of which prompted evacuations.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sheridan Fire broke out in dry brush in the hills of Alameda County. Breezy winds initially fueled the spread of the fire before it was contained https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/7/4/sheridan-fire/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the desert southwest brought warm and dry conditions across the Central Coast and Bay Area around the Fourth of July. A handful of wildfires that broke out that weekend were aided by breezy onshore winds towards the end of the weekend and into the start of the following week. Some of the fires prompted the issuance of evacuations across the region.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Park Fire broke out over Fourth of July weekend east of Morgan Hill prompting evacuations https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/7/5/park-fire/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the desert southwest brought warm and dry conditions across the Central Coast and Bay Area around the Fourth of July. A handful of wildfires that broke out that weekend were aided by breezy onshore winds towards the end of the weekend and into the start of the following week. Some of the fires prompted the issuance of evacuations across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The California Fire started in Contra Costa County near I-80. Part of Cummings Skyway near where the fire was burning was closed https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/7/6/california-fire/. End time is approximate.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the desert southwest brought warm and dry conditions across the Central Coast and Bay Area around the Fourth of July. A handful of wildfires that broke out that weekend were aided by breezy onshore winds towards the end of the weekend and into the start of the following week. Some of the fires prompted the issuance of evacuations across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Holland Fire broke out northeast of Brentwood on the 20th prompting evacuations around the area https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/7/20/holland-fire/. No structures were ultimately destroyed https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2020/07/20/firefighters-battle-east-contra-costa-grass-fire/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Holland Fire broke out northeast of Brentwood in late July. The vegetation fire was fueled by breezy winds that afternoon and prompted evacuations near the Brentwood Marina.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat wave prompts rolling blackouts across the Bay Area https://abc7news.com/bay-area-heat-wave-rolling-blackouts-california-power-outage-san-francisco/6372015/. Timing estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged and oppressive heat wave swept the Central Coast and Bay Area for almost a week from August 14th to August 19th with widespread record breaking temperatures observed across the region. This was caused by a strong high pressure system over the Desert Southwest that expanded westward into California. This dome of heat brought hot temperatures to the area for several days. Multiple days of triple digit afternoon highs were recorded inland with some coastal locations even reaching the mid 90s. Several days of hot and dry weather further dried fuels over the area increasing fire danger. During this event, a surge of monsoonal and tropical moisture from a former Tropical Storm advected northward with sufficient instability to generate multiple high based and dry thunderstorms that produced several thousand lightning strikes over the Greater Bay Area. Many locations saw wind gusts of 40-50 mph with isolated areas seeing gusts of 60-75 mph. This prompted the San Francisco Bay Area forecast office to issue a rare severe thunderstorm warning. These lightning strikes in combination with gusty and erratic outflow winds sparked hundreds of wildfires across the state of California. Several smaller fires combined to form complexes some of which are now among the largest wildfires in state history. Most of which were still actively burning at the end of August. Hundreds of thousands of acres have been burned with several hundred structures destroyed as well as a handful of deaths and injuries. Tens of thousands of residents were also forced to evacuate. Additionally, all of these wildfires burning simultaneously across the state gave the Bay Area the worst air quality in the world at one point.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Altamont RAWS station reported gusts.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After multiple lightning strikes across the region and breezy erratic winds, approximately 20 separate fires broke out across counties (Santa Clara, Alameda, Contra Costa, San Joaquin, and Stanislaus) the morning of August 16th. These fires were later re-named the SCU Lightning Complex Fires https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/8/18/scu-lightning-complex/. This complex became one of the top 5 largest fires in California State history prompting numerous evacuations, destroying nearly 400,000 acres and destroying over 200 structures. These fires resulted in 6 injuries (Civilian and Fire Personnel). The fires came dangerously close to the historic Lick Observatory on Mount Hamilton https://arstechnica.com/science/2020/08/a-california-wildfire-nearly-destroyed-the-historic-lick-observatory/. The fire was still burning at the end of August.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged and oppressive heat wave swept the Central Coast and Bay Area for almost a week from August 14th to August 19th with widespread record breaking temperatures observed across the region. Many locations saw wind gusts of 40-50 mph with isolated areas seeing gusts of 60-75 mph. This prompted the San Francisco Bay Area forecast office to issue a rare severe thunderstorm warning. These lightning strikes in combination with gusty and erratic outflow winds sparked hundreds of wildfires across the state of California. Additionally, all of these wildfires burning simultaneously across the state gave the Bay Area the worst air quality in the world at one point.

CZ_NAME_STR: EAST BAY HILLS AND THE DIABLO RANGE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The SCU Lightning Complex fires continued to burn through September before full containment was reached on the morning of October 1st. The SCU fires became the third largest wildfire in California state history. A total of 396,624 acres burned, 26 structures damaged and 222 were destroyed, and 6 people were injured by the fire that spanned 5 counties https://www.fire.ca.gov/incidents/2020/8/18/scu-lightning-complex/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Continued periods of gusty offshore winds, dry conditions, and hot to record breaking temperatures allowed the August lightning fires to burn throughout the month of September. Persistent dry conditions across the hills and above normal temperatures made fire fighting efforts difficult with relatively poor humidity recoveries for much of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The city of Richmond tied its all time record high temperature at 107 degrees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure over the west brought excessive heat and dry conditions to the region. Numerous record high temperatures were broken with 13 broken records on Sunday the 6th alone including records set that weekend for the month of September. Temperatures over the long weekend breached 110 degrees across the interior with 90s along the coast to start the weekend and even reaching 100 degrees in San Francisco on Sunday. Once the ridge began to break down towards the end of the weekend, offshore winds increased flaring up some of the wildfires that were ignited during August's lightning storm. These winds also enabled smoke from various wildfires across the state to blanket much of the Bay Area. The skies were tinted orange and red with ash accumulating for many locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Ramon CARB station reported temperatures between 26 and 28 degrees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving cold front swept through the region into the morning of the 25th bringing gusty northwest winds to coastal areas. Gusts of 40-50 mph were observed along the coast. This system also brought showers and lowering snow levels. In the wake of the front on the 25th as winds calmed and colder air settled in, overnight temperatures dropped in the valleys into the mid to upper 20s.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Livermore Fire Department reported 28 degree temperatures.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving cold front swept through the region into the morning of the 25th bringing gusty northwest winds to coastal areas. Gusts of 40-50 mph were observed along the coast. This system also brought showers and lowering snow levels. In the wake of the front on the 25th as winds calmed and colder air settled in, overnight temperatures dropped in the valleys into the mid to upper 20s.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported pea sized hail in north Pleasanton.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent cold front swept through the region bringing showers, small hail, lowering snow levels, and gusty winds along the coast. Observations recorded winds along the coast around 30-45 mph and up to 50 mph in the coastal mountains. Cameras also showed a dusting of snow over some area peaks as snow levels dropped.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Livermore station broke a daily record at 107 degrees previously 104 in 1961.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Four Corners brought a hot and dry air mass to the Central Coast and Bay Area in mid June. Hot daytime temperatures for multiple days in the triple digits resulted in record breaking heat for the interior portion of the region. Higher elevation areas reported daytime highs in the 100s with overnight lows in the 70s and 80s. Several sites broke daily record highs on June 17th. The heat lasted into the start of that coming weekend and resulted in one fatality in San Jose. Additionally, persistent hot/dry conditions along with near record dry fuels allowed for the development of the Willow Fire in Monterey County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Byron ASOS reached a daytime high of 113 degrees F and remained in the 100s until 8 pm PDT. Temperatures were still in the 80s by midnight.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure building over the region in early to mid July brought warm to hot temperatures across the interior. Daytime highs rose into the 100s with locations across the East Bay up to 110 degrees between July 9th and 11th. Overnight lows remained warm, particularly across higher elevations where temperatures were still in the 70s and 80s in the early mornings. Additionally, prolonged dry conditions resulted in near record dry fuels for July. This along with breezy afternoon winds prompted the Diablo Fire in Contra Costa County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Diablo Fire broke out in the morning on the 11th south of Byron. Breezy afternoon winds contributed to the growth of the fire. The fire was contained later that evening https://abc7news.com/byron-fire-contra-costa-county-grass-wildfire/10879543/.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure building over the region in early to mid July brought warm to hot temperatures across the interior. Daytime highs rose into the 100s with locations across the East Bay up to 110 degrees between July 9th and 11th. Overnight lows remained warm, particularly across higher elevations where temperatures were still in the 70s and 80s in the early mornings. Additionally, prolonged dry conditions resulted in near record dry fuels for July. This along with breezy afternoon winds prompted the Diablo Fire in Contra Costa County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet (PG&E) station at San Jose Mines Rd had a high temperature of 104 degrees and remained in the 80s and 90s late into the night.
